channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: As ISIS Posts in Portuguese, U.S. and Brazil Bolster Olympics Security
item.media:description: Brazilian soldiers guarded the Olympic beach volleyball arena in Rio de Janeiro last week.
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.description: Jihadists calling for mayhem at the Olympics — and Brazil’s relative inexperience in grappling with terrorism — has led to a sense of urgency in Rio.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Fathers of 1994 Bombing Victims in Argentina Keep Pushing for Justice
item.media:description: Hundreds of people in Buenos Aires held portraits of victims of the 1994 bombing attack against a Jewish center that killed 85 people. The July 17 demonstration commemorated the 21st anniversary of the attack.
item.description: The relatives of the attack on a Jewish center in Buenos Aires that killed 85 people want a criminal complaint against a former president to be reopened.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: A World Vision Donor Sponsored a Boy. The Outcome Was a Mystery to Both.
item.media:description: Young Palestinians at a private swimming pool in Husan. Othman’s aunt Myasar recalled that years ago, strangers had come to Husan with cameras and lined up the children to take photos.
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.description: An Australian asked for help years later to find out what had happened to a Palestinian, and he learned the money had aided the boy’s community — while the family never understood the cards he sent.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: A Gloomy Egypt Sees Its International Influence Wither Away
item.media:description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt, center-left, with graduates of the Air Force Academy in Cairo in July.
item.description: Long a leader of the Arab world, politically and culturally, Egypt has become inward-looking and politically marginalized in a way not seen for generations.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Rescuers Say Toxic Gas Dropped on Syrian Town Where Russian Helicopter Shot Down
item.description: A Syrian rescue service operating in rebel-held territory said on Tuesday a helicopter dropped containers of toxic gas overnight on a town close to where a Russian military helicopter had been shot down hours earlier.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Turks Can Agree on One Thing: U.S. Was Behind Failed Coup
item.media:description: An effigy of the Muslim cleric Fethullah Gulen, who lives in self-exile in the United States and has been widely blamed in Turkey for the failed coup, hanging on Tuesday in Ankara, the capital.
item.description: Turks of all stripes believe the United States was involved in the coup attempt, especially because the cleric suspected of leading it lives in Pennsylvania.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Czech Man Is Charged With Attempted Terrorism
item.description: The authorities said the 25-year-old mechanic’s arrest was the first known case of a Czech citizen trying to join the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and JAN RICHTER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Pope Sets Up Vatican Panel to Study Female Deacons Issue
item.description: Pope Francis has set up a panel to study whether women could serve as deacons, a role now reserved to men.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Body Count Rises as Philippine President Wages War on Drugs
item.media:description: Jennilyn Olayres weeping over the body of her husband, Michael Siaron, who was killed in the Manila metropolitan area last month.
item.description: Since Rodrigo Duterte took office in June, promising a tough stance on drug suspects, more than 400 people have been killed, the news media said.
item.dc:creator: JASON GUTIERREZ

item.title: Birdsville Journal: How Does an Australian Town of 100 Attract Tourists? A Music Festival and Camel Pie
item.media:description: The Big Red Bash is named for the 90-foot-tall sand dune on which it is usually held, just outside Birdsville.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The far reaches of the Australian desert can be an unforgiving place, but in this tiny town in the corner of Queensland, being remote is the attraction.
item.dc:creator: CLARISSA SEBAG-MONTEFIORE

item.title: Panel Calls for Prosecution of Nigerian Soldiers in Killings of Hundreds of Shiites
item.media:description: Shiites in Srinagar, Kashmir, protested in December 2015 against the Nigerian government’s detention of Sheikh Ibrahim Zakzaky.
item.description: A judicial inquiry outlined clashes that began when a military convoy approached a roadblock set up by members of the Islamic Movement of Nigeria.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: ‘There’s Something Going On in Turkey,’ U.S. Colonel Was Told During Coup Attempt
item.media:description: The Incirlik Air Base in southern Turkey. The day after the coup attempt last month, the country allowed Americans to begin flying air missions from there again, officials said.
item.media:credit: Ibrahim Erikan/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.description: Senior American military officers at Incirlik Air Base scrambled to figure out what was happening, and reverberations were felt directly at the installation.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Zhai Yanmin, Chinese Rights Activist, Gets Suspended Prison Term
item.media:description: Zhai Yanmin at court Tianjin, China, on Tuesday. He is expected to face strict surveillance and restrictions on his activities.
item.description: Mr. Zhai worked for a Beijing law firm that was at the center of the crackdown on human rights lawyers last year, which ensnared about 250 people.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Turkish Gold Trader Builds a Dream Team of Defense Lawyers
item.media:description: Reza Zarrab in 2013. Mr. Zarrab’s legal fees are not known, but if his case goes to trial, they could run in the tens of millions of dollars.
item.description: Reza Zarrab, who is charged with conspiracy to violate the United States sanctions on Iran, has hired more than a dozen lawyers, many of them among the most accomplished in their field.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: U.N. Deadlocked Over Draft Agreement on Refugees and Migrants
item.description: Every sentence in a 22-page document has been argued over, and an agreement that was expected to pass on Monday has been postponed.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: The Interpreter: Donald Trump Finds a Russian Policy He Won’t Defend
item.media:description: A pro-Russia rally in Yevpatoria, Crimea, in March 2014, shortly before the Russian annexation.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: That Mr. Trump for once backed out of a controversy underscores how much Russia’s meddling in Ukraine, and its annexation of Crimea, outraged world leaders.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: Muslims and Christians in French Town Pray Old Bonds Survive Priest’s Murder
item.media:description: Mass on Sunday at the Rouen Cathedral, and services across France, brought together Muslims and Christians paying tribute to Father Jacques Hamel, who was murdered last week by young jihadist men.
item.description: Efforts to strengthen interfaith ties resonated particularly in St.-Étienne-du-Rouvray, where Father Jacques Hamel was killed in the name of the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE

item.title: Iran’s Top Leader Distances Himself from Nuclear Pact, Which He Once Supported
item.media:description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei in Tehran on Monday. He accused the United States of breaching its promises in the nuclear accord reached a year ago.
item.media:credit: Office of the Iranian Supreme Leader, via Associated Press
item.description: In bellicose remarks, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said the United States was not abiding by the nuclear accord, calling it an instructive lesson.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: China Frees Wang Yu, Human Rights Lawyer, After Videotaped Confession
item.media:description: Wang Yu, a human rights lawyer who was accused of subverting state power, in Beijing last year.
item.description: Colleagues suggested coercion, not guilt, motivated a confession given by a human rights lawyer who was detained during a crackdown on dissent.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Thousands of Indian Workers Are Stuck in Saudi Arabia as Kingdom’s Economy Sags
item.media:description: India’s minister of external affairs, Sushma Swaraj.
item.description: More than 10,000 Indians have recently lost their jobs in Saudi Arabia, and many are stranded there after a steep drop in the price of oil.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: British Decision on Nuclear Plant Angers China and France
item.media:description: The Hinkley Point B power station in Somerset, England. Prime Minister Theresa May has postponed a decision on a new nuclear plant, to be built by France and partly funded by China, until the fall.
item.media:credit: Andrew Matthews/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: Prime Minister Theresa May’s decision to delay the project is seen as a potentially major break from her predecessor’s policy toward Beijing.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: In an Effort to Maintain U.S. Ties, Turkey Softens Its Tone
item.media:description: Supporters of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey during a protest in Cologne, Germany, on Sunday.
item.description: When a top American general met with officials in the Turkish capital he heard no suggestion that the United States had played a role in the failed coup attempt.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and TIM ARANGO
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: U.S. Conducts Airstrikes Against ISIS in Libya
item.media:description: President Obama approved strikes against Islamic State fighters last week after Libya’s fragile United Nations-backed unity government asked for help in its fight against the militants, administration officials said.
item.description: The strikes in Surt were part of a new military campaign against the Sunni terrorist group’s stronghold in North Africa, the Pentagon said.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Russian Military Helicopter Is Shot Down in Syria, Killing 5
item.description: The aircraft was hit by ground fire as it returned from a mission to Aleppo, according to a statement from the Russian Defense Ministry.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Sinosphere: Taiwan’s President Apologizes to Aborigines for Centuries of Injustice
item.description: “We must tell the truth,” President Tsai Ing-wen said. “And then, most importantly, the government must genuinely reflect on this past.”
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: What in the World: In France, a Recipe Squabble over Marseille Soap
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; Photos by neydtstock, nulinukas, nika novak, kai keisuke/shutterstock
item.description: Soapmakers want the government to protect their storied product from foreign imitations — if only they could agree on how to make the genuine article.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: What in the World: Cambodia, Home of ‘The Killing Fields,’ Becomes a Retirement Haven
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; photos by Whitelook, Sonya Etchison, Kudla, R Foto/Shutterstock
item.description: Foreigners are finding that their Social Security dollars go far in a country once racked by war and genocide — and the government is glad to have them.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: What in the World: How Do You Say ‘Hashtag’ or ‘Shaming’ in Ancient Hebrew?
item.description: The Academy of the Hebrew Language is always working to update and expand a vocabulary that was once inscribed on parchment.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Obama’s American Idea
item.media:description: On May 26, 1996, Mariana Cook visited Barack and Michelle Obama in Hyde Park as part of a photography project on couples in America.
item.media:credit: Mariana Cook/Courtesy Lee Marks Fine Art
item.description: There is no real America to take back, as Trump insists, because America’s many-hued reality is a ceaseless becoming.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Turkey’s Fractured State
item.media:description: A statue of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, seen through a damaged window at Ankara police headquarters.
item.description: The coup attempt brought the Erdogan-Gulen conflict into the open. Can the damage be repaired?
item.dc:creator: HALIL M. KARAVELI
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The New Ideology of the New Cold War
item.description: Russia isn’t just pushing its interests. It is advocating a new, anti-liberal worldview.
item.dc:creator: JOCHEN BITTNER

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Voices From Europe’s Far Right
item.media:description: “Our economy doesn’t increase along with the never-ending supply of immigrants,” wrote Mikael Jakobsen, 24, a law student in Aarhus, Denmark.
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of readers from across the Continent responded to our call to share their experiences as supporters of far-right parties.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
